journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Total hip arthroplasty by using a cementless ultrashort stem: A subject-specific finite element analysis for a young patient clinical case

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Electronic Engineering, Chemistry and Industrial Engineering, University of Messina, Messina, Italy
2Department of Special Surgery, Division of Traumatology and Orthopedics, University of Messina, Messina, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Gabriella Epasto, Department of Electronic Engineering, Chemistry and Industrial Engineering, University of Messina, Contrada di Dio, Loc. Sant’Agata, 98166 Messina, Italy. Email: gabriella.epasto@unime.it

abstract.p: In this article, a subject-specific finite element analysis has been developed to study a clinical case of a surgically misaligned hip prosthesis with an ultrashort stem. It was set out to study the strain energy density pattern, comparing the results obtained with computed tomography images. The authors developed two other numerical models: the first one analyzes the stress and strain distributions in the healthy femur (without prosthesis) and the second one analyzes the same boneimplant biomechanical system of the clinical case but assuming the prosthesis in the proper position. The misaligned prosthesis produced an overload at the proximal posterior plane of the femur, as confirmed by computed tomography images, which detect the formation of new bone. The numerical model of the correctly positioned prosthesis demonstrated that the bone is not overloaded and that the position of neutral axis does not significantly shift from the physiological condition.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The conservation of bone stock by minimizing bone resorption due to stress shielding1 is a vitally important aspect, especially when considering that cementless femoral implants are typically used in the total hip arthroplasty (THA) of young patients in whom the possibility of a revision procedure during the patient’s lifetime is expected and the need to keep reconstructive options opened is essential. To minimize the stress-shielding bone resorption, anatomically designed implants have been developed with a conical and undersized distal apex or with a distal split section. The shape prevents distal load transfer by avoiding contact between the diaphyseal femoral cortex and the implant itself.2 The latter increases the elasticity of the distal portion of the implant allowing it to bend with the diaphyseal bone during loading. A polished surface that prevents bone ingrowth, and, hence, implant fixation, may further reduce distal load transfer. Obviously, the best way to preserve the bone stock and to reduce stress-shielding bone resorption of the proximal femur is obtained by suppressing or removing the distal stem of the femoral component and providing metaphyseal fixation (ultrashort prosthesis).

A new short-stemmed prosthesis (Proxima™, DePuy International, Leeds, UK) has been designed with a close anatomical fit to the proximal cortex, with the aim of maximizing primary stability, particularly in torsion. It is also proposed that the shorter shaft leads to more physiological loading of the femur, thereby limiting potential bone resorption due to stress shielding.

The main goal of this study was the analysis of a real scenario due to a complex clinical case of a misaligned prosthesis. A subject-specific finite element (FE) model of a THA was developed by using a computed tomography (CT) dataset3 –5 in order to evaluate the contact status and stress–strain distribution at bone–prosthesis interface. The results of the FE analysis were compared with the CT images.

The determination of the mechanical stresses that physiological activities induce in human bones is of great importance in both research and clinical practices. Unfortunately, the mechanical stress in bones cannot be measured in living subjects without the use of an invasive surgical procedure, which, in general, is not ethically permissible. The only noninvasive way to estimate bone stresses is the subject-specific FE modeling. This procedure is based on numerical modeling of the bone from the CT images. CT represents the method of choice for the generation of the FE models of bone segments. However, the accuracy of the results obtained through FE model depends on the accuracy of the simulation of the model and the optimized mesh generation.

In the natural state, the stress is distributed over the entire cross section of the femur. Bending and axial compression are the major modes of loading. The postsurgery stress state is significantly different mainly due to the manner in which the load is transferred to the femur.

Subject-specific FE modeling has commonly been employed to assess the stress state and fracture risk of bone structures, such as long bones,6
–9 spine10,11 and other bones.12
–15 Several studies focused on bone remodeling algorithm.16 –18 Some authors19 –21 employed FE simulations to evaluate the initial extent of stress shielding in order to relate stress shielding to bone loss. An FE model, once validated, can predict the entire stress field and is an easy way to verify the structural behavior of a biomechanical system for different types of stress and also to simulate different surgical techniques and presurgery choices, as custom-made implants.22 –24

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The clinical case analyzed in this article refers to a 1.60-m-tall, 31-year-old female in whom the stem was surgically misaligned. The surgical error was detected after 30 days from the surgery, thanks to an X-ray examination. However, the patient did not report any hip pain and carried on spending a normal life. Patient clinical history was radiographically and clinically checked by means of periodical inspections with the Harris hip score.

The range of motion is full (flexion, adduction, abduction and external rotation); the patient can perform independently any activity without the aid of sticks. The patient was subjected to a CT scan to assess the bone biological activity, the callus formation and the stem stability. After 2 years from the surgery, the patient does not complain pain, functional limitations and any impediments. During the last evaluation, the patient was examined using a Harris hip score. In a movement evaluation scale, flexion ranged between 90° and 100°, abduction between 15° and 20°, external rotation between 10° and 15° and adduction between 10° and 15°. After a complete evaluation, the patient made a score of 98 (an excellent score) adding the radiographic control score that was considered regular. As a consequence of such clinical history, even though the prosthesis was misaligned, this research has been developed.

The position of the prosthesis in the proximal femur was reconstructed from the CT scans of the patient (Figure 1). The woman was subjected to a bilateral total hip replacement (THR); the femur studied in this research was the left one. The scan was carried out at about 24 months from the surgery.

caption.p: CT scan of the proximal femur. The green mask shows the analyzed proximal femur.

sec.p: Three FE models were constructed: one representing the intact bone, one the postoperative treated bone with the implant surgically misaligned and the third representing an ideal case with the implant correctly positioned.

The anatomy reconstructions were based on the woman’s CT dataset, using Mimics® Software (Materialise, Leuven, Belgium). The resolution of the CT images and the slice distance will affect the accuracy of the model. For this project, a CT scan with a resolution of 512 × 512 pixels was used, with a resulting pixel size of 0.742 mm, and the scan was reconstructed into 1-mm slices. The total number of slices in the scan was 265, and the scan was performed using 0° gantry tilt. The authors could not reconstruct the femur geometry directly due to many artifacts in the CT data (Figure 1); thus, the FE models of three femurs were obtained importing the “standard femur”25 in the CT environment and scaling its dimensions according to the CT dataset of the patient’s femur. A previous study26 has shown that the sensitivity of stress and strain predictions is affected by the uncertainties related to the femur geometry and the bone density for less than 9%.

This procedure allowed the authors to analyze a real scenario in which the prosthesis was surgically misaligned. The short, metaphyseal-fitting femoral component considered in this study is a cementless Proxima stem. The Proxima stem is made of titanium alloy (9 sizes in each side; lengths 55.1–102 mm) and is entirely porous coated with sintered titanium beads having a mean pore size of 250 µm, to which hydroxyapatite is coated (a thickness of 30 µm), except for the distal tip, and stepped to minimize shear forces. The implanted stem analyzed in this research was of size 2. A key feature of the Proxima stem design is the medial metaphyseal area, which is proximally longer when compared to a conventional stem; this feature allows for a higher horizontal femoral neck cut (at head–neck juncture), thus preserving the medial portion of the neck, which is usually sacrificed during femoral neck osteotomy with conventional femoral stems. The second key feature of this implant is the highly pronounced lateral flare, which allows the implant to laterally rest where the arciform fibers end on the greater trochanter. The rationale of this design is to obtain full load transfer onto the proximal femur.

The most efficient method for the required data processing was to convert the three-dimensional (3D) model into an stl file format (i.e. a format designed for stereolithography) that can be converted into a 3D solid mesh by Altair HyperMesh® software.

The resulting 3D model volume was discretized using eight-node, linear, hexahedral elements in Altair HyperMesh environment. Element size of 1 mm was chosen, which resulted in 425,076 elements for the whole assembly. A perfect interface boundary condition was used to simulate the entire interface between the cancellous and cortical bones (Figure 2(a) and (b)).

caption.p: Proximal femur for the analyzed clinical case: the assemblies after mesh generation: (a) mediolateral view and (b) anterior–posterior view.

sec.p: The cancellous bone was considered as an isotropic material in the FE analysis, while cortical bone was considered as orthotropic. An average value of Hounsfield units (HU) index was evaluated by CT data for both cortical and cancellous bones in the proximal femur using Mimics software. The bone material properties were assumed homogenous over all the femur and evaluated considering the average value of HU index. Mineral density was derived from the CT HU using a linear relationship equation.5 The mechanical properties of cortical and cancellous bones are calculated according to equations reported in the literature.3,5,27,28

The relationship between density and mechanical properties (elastic and shear moduli) for cortical and cancellous bones is reported in Table 1 and the obtained material properties are listed in Table 2.

caption.p: Relationships between density and elastic constants for cortical and cancellous bones. The properties are labeled from 1 to 3 (axial), corresponding to the Cartesian directions x, y and z, respectively.
Mechanical properties of cortical and cancellous bones used in the FE model.

sec.p: The Proxima stem, made of Ti alloy (Ti6Al4V), was considered in the FE analysis to be a linear, elastic, isotropic material with the following mechanical properties: an elastic modulus equal to 110,000 MPa and a Poisson’s ratio equal to 0.3.

A contact function was implemented at the prosthesis–cancellous bone interface,29 assuming a fully integrated prosthesis (glue option). The software MSC Marc Mentat® was used as a solver. The effect of any residual strains at the interface due to an initial press fit was neglected, since the stem was assumed fully integrated, as suggested by the 18-month X-ray follow-up and by the clinical history of the patient.

The assigned boundary conditions were simplified, with the distal part of the proximal femur fully constrained in all directions. The vectors of the muscle forces in the femur were based on data reported by Taylor et al.30 The monopodalic static loads were applied in the FE model considering a body weight of 750 N (Table 3).

caption.p: List of muscles included in all the FE models. The magnitude of muscle forces based on the study by Taylor et al.30 is given considering a body weight of 750 N.

sec.p: Due to the use of only the proximal femur, none of the muscles attaching beyond the mid-distal femur was included. As the muscles, which are activated during gait, are numerous and differ in intensity and direction, it has been demonstrated31,32 that it is possible to consider only the principal muscles in the FE analyses, obtaining reliable results.
The Cartesian axes are defined, so that the XZ plane defines the anterior–posterior (AP) view and the YZ plane defines the mediolateral (ML) one (Figure 2(a) and (b)).

The authors developed two other numerical models: the first one analyzes the stress and strain distributions in the healthy femur (without prosthesis) and the second one analyzes the same bone–implant biomechanical system of the clinical case but assuming the prosthesis in the proper position. The load values of the two FE models were the same as those considered in the numerical model that reproduces the clinical case. The numerical model of the femur without prosthesis was implemented by means of the standard femur25 to which was, in a second FE model, cut the femoral head and the prosthesis was successfully inserted. The neck of the femur was sectioned according to a proximally placed cutting plane, immediately below the piriformis fossa. This surgical choice allows the preservation of the femoral neck.33

The geometry of the cancellous bone was obtained in the FE model through the implementation of a volume between the cortical bone and the prosthesis; it was subsequently discretized. All components (the implant, cancellous bone and cortical bone) were discretized using tetrahedral elements with a size of 1 mm. The nodes of the elements of cancellous and cortical bones have been merged in the numerical model in order to have continuity between the two materials. MSC Marc Mentat contact function has been applied at cancellous bone–implant interface with the glue option (i.e. fully osseointegrated stem).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The pattern of axial stress along the z direction (σ33) is shown in Figure 3 for the analysis of the location of the bending neutral axis. The comparison between the numerical model of the healthy femur and the one with the correctly positioned prosthesis shows that the prosthesis does not significantly shift the position of the neutral axis, as it is found in physiological conditions (Figure 3(a) and (c)).

caption.p: (a) Compressive stress on the surface of the healthy femur; (b) compressive stress on the surface of the investigated biomechanical system and (c) compressive stress on the surface of the femur–stem biomechanical system.

sec.p: The misaligned stem, as that of the clinical case, involves a shift of the neutral axis toward the lateral plane, and the presence of a significant XZ plane diverted bending (Figure 3(b)). The contact stress due to the presence of the prosthesis causes a strong functional overload of the femur in the AP plane of the metaphysis.

As calculated by the numerical model, the implant causes bone overload, resulting in higher values of strain energy density (SED; Figure 4(a)). This is confirmed by CT images (Figure 4(b)): high strains are a strong mechanical stimulus for the bone, which tends to remodel and strengthening where required. This involves the formation of new bone. New cortex bone (HU index mean value equal to 1245) was detected by CT images where the implant passes through the femur (in green, cortical bone HU index threshold was set).

caption.p: (a) Strain energy density in sagittal plane for the investigated case and (b) postoperative CT images of the sagittal plane obtained 2 years after surgery show that Proxima stem is solidly fixed but in a wrong position. The peak values of SED suggest that bone remodeling will occur; this assumption is confirmed by HU index value around periprosthetic bone.

sec.p: The high value of stress indicates bone pain, but this value does not exceed the local average ultimate strength reported in the literature,34 and therefore, should not constitute a danger, considering also that in this FE model, bone remodeling was not considered, so the cross section is smaller than that indicated by CT.

Functional overload was also found near the toe of the prosthesis (Figure 5(a)). The CT images confirm the numerical data also in this case by means of the detection of HU mean values for stiff callus (HU mean value equal to about 726) and new cortical bone (HU mean value equal to about 1017, as shown in Figure 5(b)).

caption.p: (a) Strain energy density in the femur diaphysis, near the toe of the prosthesis, and (b) CT slice of the diaphysis section, near the toe of the prosthesis. In the CT data is shown the HU index for new periprosthetic bone.

sec.p: Distribution of SED in the proximal femur, categorized by Gruen zones, showed differences due to changes in prosthesis position as well as between implanted and intact femur models (Figure 6).

caption.p: Strain energy density in the intact femur (left), in the analyzed clinical case (middle) and with the prosthesis correctly positioned (right). The intertrochanteric line refers to proximal Gruen zones I–VII.

sec.p: In the most proximal Gruen zone VII (in compression) of the clinical and normopositioned models, SEDs were 0.14–0.05 kJ/m3 smaller than the reference model 0.21 kJ/m3 (Table 4).

caption.p: SED values of the nonpathological, the clinical case and ideally positioned prosthesis with respect to the proximal Gruen zones I–VII and to the toe of the prosthesis (only for the clinical case). In the table is also given a prediction of bone remodeling by estimating the RBREF parameter.

sec.p: According to the results obtained by FE models, the misaligned prosthesis can cause bone deposition in the area near the toe, as functional overload and high value of SED were detected. On the contrary, in Gruen zone VII, bone resorption may occur. HU index evaluated in the CT images confirms this assumption. The value is near the lowest threshold for cortical bone (HU average value about 630; Figure 7).

caption.p: CT slice of the Gruen zone VII. The value of HU index shows a lower density than the mean value evaluated for the proximal cortical bone, indicating stress shielding due to the misalignment of the prosthesis.

sec.p: The normopositioned FE model assesses that in the Gruen zones I–VII, bone deposition and bone resorption, respectively, may minimally occur as SED values are very close to the threshold values of RBRES.

Further validation of the developed numerical models derives from the evaluation of principal stresses and strains for the case of healthy femur and of the one with properly positioned prosthesis, using data coming from the literature. The values calculated in the numerical model of the intact femur do not differ much from that reported by Polgar et al.,27 while for what concerns the second case, it is confirmed the assumption that the short-stem prostheses are a good preoperative choice to minimize the risk of bone resorption due to stress shielding.2,33,35 The peak value of compressive stress in the medial plane decreases to about 25% with respect to the physiological conditions. In the lateral plane, the insertion of the prosthesis involves a reduction of the stress value less than 30%. In a previous work,36 it has been shown that traditional implants with long stem involve a decrease in physiological load up to 40% in the medial plane and 50% in the lateral one, causing bone resorption in the Gruen zones I–VII.

In previous works,37,38 it is also reported that this prosthesis ensures a strong axial and torsional stability and less risk of loosening. This behavior is probably due to the fact that the load is circumferential on the femur. This assumption is confirmed only in the ML plane for X-stress and Y-stress, although the values referred to a healthy metaphysis, just below the trochanteric fossa, are quite small.

The analyzed clinical case, even if the prosthesis is misaligned, shows a strong stability of the latter, as demonstrated by the patient’s clinical history. In this case, the implant transfers loads to the bone, both in the AP plane (σ11; Figure 8(a)) and in the ML plane (σ22; Figure 8(b)). This stress pattern could also be an explanation of the prosthesis stability.

caption.p: Stress pattern for the investigated clinical case: (a) stress along x direction σ11 and (b) stress along y direction σ22.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The aim of this scientific research was the study of a THA clinical case where the prosthesis was surgically misaligned. It was developed a “custom” FE model, where the term “custom” has a triple meaning.

First, the biomechanical modeling of the femur–stem system and the spatial positioning of the stem were carried out by means of a reverse engineering procedure from 3D CT images of the clinical case. However, it should be pointed out that it was not possible to use the whole femur of the patient to implement the numerical analysis due to numerous artifacts in CT. The authors had to employ a “modified” standard femur.

Second, the term subject-specific refers to the fact that, in the numerical analysis, the real mechanical properties of the femur were used and obtained from the relationship between CT HU index, the density and elastic constants (Young’s modulus, shear modulus and Poisson’s ratio) of cortical and cancellous bones.

Third, the results of numerical analysis in terms of SED were compared with the CT images. It was evaluated that, when detected a functional overload (thus, high SED) on cortical bone, there was the presence of bone deposition.

The FE analysis for the clinical case was compared with two other models referred to the case of a healthy femur (without prosthesis) and to the case of the presence of a correctly positioned prosthesis. The boundary conditions were the same for all FE models.

Through the cross-analysis of data already present in the literature relating to (1) comparisons between standard and ultrashort stem prostheses and (2) comparisons between loading conditions and physiological alterations induced by the presence of traditional and short-stemmed hip prosthesis, it can be confirmed that FE analysis can be an effective tool for the evaluation of complex clinical cases.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: E Young’s modulus (MPa)
G shear modulus (MPa)
RBRES risk for long-time excessive bone resorption of the periprosthetic bone (%)
Sref nonpathological value of the strain energy density (kJ/m3)
Sc value of the strain energy density (kJ/m3) for the clinical case
Sn value of the strain energy density (kJ/m3) for the normopositioned case
ν Poisson’s ratio
ρ bone mineral density (kg/m3)
σ11 axial stress along x direction (MPa)
σ22 axial stress along y direction (MPa)
σ33 axial stress along z direction (MPa)
